div.div: δῖος, δῖα, δῖον (δῖϝος, Διός): divine, an epithet applied with great freedom and with consequent weakening of force; only fem. as applied to gods, δῖα θεά̄, Il. 10.290; δἶ Ἀφροδί̄τη, so δῖα θεά̄ων, also δῖα γυναικῶν, ‘divine of women’; applied to Charybdis, Od. 12.104; to the swineherd Eumaeus (‘noble’), Od. 16.56; to one of Hector's horses, Il. 8.185; also to inanimate things, the sea, earth, lands, rivers.
From A Homeric Dictionary (Georg Autenrieth, New York, Harper and Brothers, 1891)
